passage:
(1) Hurricanes are powerful tropical storms that form over warm ocean waters and can cause devastating damage when they reach land. These massive weather systems, also known as cyclones or typhoons in different parts of the world, are characterized by strong winds, heavy rainfall, and storm surges that can flood coastal areas. When a hurricane makes landfall, it can destroy buildings, uproot trees, and cause extensive flooding that affects communities for weeks or even months after the storm has passed.

(2) The formation of a hurricane begins with warm ocean water, typically at least 80°F (27°C), which provides the energy needed to fuel these powerful storms. As warm, moist air rises from the ocean surface, it creates an area of low pressure below. More air rushes in to fill this space, becomes warm and moist, and also rises. This continuous process forms clouds and thunderstorms while creating a circular pattern of winds around the low-pressure center. If conditions remain favorable, this system can strengthen into a tropical depression, then a tropical storm, and finally a hurricane.

(3) Hurricanes are classified using the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale, which ranges from Category 1 (winds of 74-95 mph) to Category 5 (winds over 157 mph). The higher the category, the more destructive potential the hurricane has. At the center of a hurricane is the eye, a relatively calm area typically 20-40 miles wide. Surrounding the eye is the eyewall, where the most severe weather and strongest winds occur. Rain bands extending outward from the eyewall can bring heavy precipitation to areas hundreds of miles from the hurricane's center.

(4) Climate change is affecting hurricanes in several important ways. Warmer ocean temperatures provide more energy for hurricanes to form and intensify, potentially leading to stronger storms. Rising sea levels increase the risk and impact of storm surges, pushing more water inland during hurricanes. There is also evidence suggesting that hurricanes may be moving more slowly, allowing them to drop more rain in one area and increasing flood risks. Scientists continue to study these trends to better understand how hurricane patterns may change in the future.

(5) Preparing for hurricanes is essential for people living in vulnerable coastal areas. Early warning systems using satellites and aircraft reconnaissance help meteorologists track hurricanes and predict their paths. This information allows authorities to issue evacuation orders when necessary. Individuals can prepare by creating emergency plans, assembling supply kits, and securing their homes. Communities can develop infrastructure like seawalls and storm drainage systems to reduce damage. Despite these efforts, hurricanes remain one of nature's most powerful and destructive forces, reminding us of the importance of both preparation and respect for the natural world.

questions.question: Choose the correct verb form: I _____ to the movies last weekend.
Select the appropriate tense: By the time we arrive, the movie _____.
Which sentence is grammatically correct?
Choose the correct conditional form: If I _____ rich, I would travel around the world.
Which is the correct comparative form?

options.A: This book is more interesting than that one.
options.B: This book is interestinger than that one.
options.C: This book is more interestinger than that one.
options.D: This book is most interesting than that one.

questions.question: Select the correct form of the verb: The dishes _____ by my brother yesterday.
Choose the correct form: She _____ for three hours when I called her.
Select the correct modal verb: You _____ smoke in this building. It's against the rules.
Choose the correct question form: _____ to London before?
Select the appropriate article: I saw _____ interesting movie last night.
Identify the correct relative pronoun: The woman _____ lives next door is a doctor.
Which sentence has the correct word order?

options.A: I know where is the restaurant.
options.B: I know where the restaurant is.
options.C: I know the restaurant where is.
options.D: I know is where the restaurant.

questions.question: Choose the correct preposition: I'm going to meet my friends _____ the weekend.
Select the appropriate quantifier: There isn't _____ milk left in the fridge.
Identify the correct reported speech: He said, 'I am going to the store.'

options.A: He said that he is going to the store.
options.B: He said that he was going to the store.
options.C: He said that I am going to the store.
options.D: He said that I was going to the store.

questions.question: Choose the appropriate expression: The meeting was canceled _____ the bad weather.
Select the correct phrasal verb: Could you please _____ this form with your personal information?
Choose the correct collocation: She needs to _____ a decision about her future soon.
Select the appropriate connector: I wanted to go to the beach; _____, it started raining.
Choose the correct expression: I don't mind _____ the dishes after dinner.
Select the appropriate idiom: When I had to give a speech in front of the class, I completely _____.
Choose the correct form: I wish I _____ to the party last night.
Select the appropriate preposition: The book was written _____ a famous author.
Choose the correct expression: I'm really looking _____ to my vacation next month.
Select the appropriate response to 'Thank you': _____

options.D: Both B and C are correct

questions.question: The professor gave an interesting _____ on climate change last week.

Could you _____ how this machine works? I don't understand the instructions.
The _____ forecast says it will rain tomorrow, so bring an umbrella.
I don't like this restaurant. Let's try _____ place for dinner.
The teacher used a _____ to show how the water cycle works.
Her political views are quite _____, supporting personal freedoms and social progress.

The company plans to _____ its new product with a big advertising campaign.
The hotel will _____ free breakfast for all guests.
Regular exercise and a balanced diet are essential for a _____ lifestyle.
This is a _____ example of Renaissance architecture.
The charity organization provides _____ for homeless people in the city.
It is _____ to park your car in front of the fire hydrant.
According to paragraph 1, hurricanes are also known as:

options.C: cyclones or typhoons in different parts of the world

questions.question: What is the minimum water temperature typically needed for hurricane formation?
According to paragraph 3, what is the eye of a hurricane?

options.A: The area with the strongest winds
options.B: A relatively calm area at the center
options.C: The area that forms first in a hurricane
options.D: The outer edge of a hurricane

questions.question: Which category of hurricane has winds over 157 mph according to the passage?
According to paragraph 4, how is climate change affecting hurricanes?

options.A: It is reducing the number of hurricanes
options.B: It is causing hurricanes to move faster
options.C: It may lead to stronger storms due to warmer ocean temperatures
options.D: It has no effect on hurricane formation

questions.question: What does the passage suggest about hurricanes moving more slowly?

options.A: It reduces the amount of rainfall
options.C: It makes hurricanes easier to predict

questions.question: Based on paragraph 5, what tools are used to track hurricanes?
The passage suggests that which of the following helps communities reduce hurricane damage?
What is the main idea of the passage?

options.A: How to predict when hurricanes will occur
options.B: How hurricanes form, their effects, and preparation methods
options.C: Why hurricanes are more dangerous than other natural disasters
options.D: The history of hurricanes around the world

questions.question: What does the passage imply about hurricanes in its conclusion?

options.A: They can be completely controlled by modern technology
options.B: They are becoming less destructive over time
options.C: They remain powerful forces of nature despite our preparations
options.D: They will eventually disappear due to climate change
